title: Djelfa
text:
Djelfa ( is the capital city of <a href="Djelfa%20Province">Djelfa Province</a>, <a href="Algeria">Algeria</a> and the site of ancient city and former bishopric Fallaba, which remains a Latin catholic <a href="titular%20see">titular see</a>.
It has a population of 339,248 (2008 census). The city lies at the junction of the N1 and the N46 roads.
Geography.
Djelfa is located at an elevation of 3,734 feet (1,138 m) in the <a href="Ouled%20Na%C3%AFl%20Range">Ouled Naïl Range</a> of north-central <a href="Algeria">Algeria</a>, between the towns of <a href="Bou%20Sa%C3%A2da">Bousaada</a> and <a href="Laghouat">Laghouat</a>. It is situated in a transitional zone between the dry, steppe-like <a href="Hautes%20Plaines">Hautes Plaines</a> (high plateaus) of the north, characterized by <a href="chott">chott</a>s (intermittent salt lakes), and the <a href="Sahara">Sahara</a> to the south. The town was founded in 1852 as a French military post on a geometric plan. It serves as an important <a href="livestock">livestock</a> market centre for the semi-<a href="nomad">nomad</a>ic <a href="Ouled%20Na%C3%AFl">Ouled Naïl</a> confederation. Djelfa is on the 12,000 mile-long Africa Trail.
The surrounding region for centuries has been the meeting place of the <a href="Ouled%20Na%C3%AFl">Ouled Naïl</a> people, who live in black-and-red striped tents and claim descent from the Islamic prophet, <a href="Muhammad">Muhammad</a>.
History.
The area is notable for its abundance of <a href="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> <a href="rock%20carving">rock carving</a>s dating from 7000 to 5000 BC. North of Djelfa town there is an imposing physical feature known as <a href="Rocher%20de%20Sel">Rocher de Sel</a> (English: Salt Rock) that resulted from the erosion of rock salts and marls by rain. To the west of the town Megalithic funerary structures are found.
During the <a href="Roman%20Empire">Roman Empire</a> a <a href="civitas">Roman town</a> called Fallaba was built on the site of Djelfa. That town lasted unto <a href="late%20antiquity">late antiquity</a>.
In the 11th century, the <a href="Fatimid%20Caliphate">Fatimids</a> sent the <a href="Banu%20Hilal">Banu Hilal</a> to the <a href="Tripolitania">Tripolitania</a>, <a href="Tunisia">Tunisia</a> and <a href="Constantine%20Province">Constantine</a> areas against the <a href="Zirid%20dynasty">Zirids</a>.
During <a href="Philippe%20P%C3%A9tain">Philippe Pétain</a>'s period, a concentration camp was placed in Djelfa.
Ecclesiastical history.
During the <a href="Vandal%20Kingdom">Vandal Kingdom</a> and <a href="Roman%20Empire">Roman Empire</a> the town was the <a href="cathedra">seat</a> of an <a href="classical%20antiquity">ancient</a> <a href="bishopric">bishopric</a>. The bishopric was important enough in the Late <a href="Roman%20province">Roman province</a> of <a href="Numidia">Numidia</a> to become one of the many <a href="suffragan%20bishop">suffragan bishop</a>rics of its Metropolitan Archbishopric in <a href="Carthage">Carthage</a>.
It is possible that Christianity came to the town only after the rule of <a href="Constantine%20the%20Great">Constantine the Great</a>, as there is no record of the bishopric under the <a href="Ancient%20Rome">Romans</a>. 
The only known bishop of this African diocese is the Catholic bishop Salo mentioned in 484. This is considerably late compared to many of the other diocese in Numidia. Bishop Salo took part in the <a href="Council%20of%20Carthage%20%28484%29">synod assembled in Carthage in 484</a> by the <a href="Arianism">Arian</a> ruler, <a href="Huneric">Huneric</a> of the <a href="Vandal%20Kingdom">Vandal Kingdom</a>; after the Synod Salo was exiled (probably) to Vandal-controlled Sicily.
Like most bishoprics in <a href="Diocese%20of%20Africa">Roman Africa</a>, it faded after the <a href="Muslim%20conquest%20of%20the%20Maghreb">Muslim conquest of the Maghreb</a>.
Titular see.
In 1933 the diocese was nominally restored as <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Church">Latin Catholic</a> <a href="titular%20bishopric">titular bishopric</a>.
It has had the following incumbents, mostly of the fitting episcopal (lowest) rank "with an archiepiscopal (intermediary) exception :
Culture.
The inhabitants are also <a href="Ouled%20Na%C3%AFl">Ouled Naïl</a> living in <a href="Biskra">Biskra</a>, <a href="M%27Sila%2C%20Algeria">M'Sila</a> and in <a href="Saharan%20Atlas">Saharan Atlas</a>.
Climate.
Djelfa has a <a href="semi-arid%20climate">semi-arid climate</a> (<a href="K%C3%B6ppen%20climate%20classification">Köppen climate classification</a> "BSk"), with more precipitation in winter than in summer. Snow is not unusual in winter.
